title.value: Spatial variations in aromatic hydrocarbon emission in a dust-rich galaxy
title.justification: This is the title of the paper as provided in the user query.
title.quote: Spatial variations in aromatic hydrocarbon emission in a dust-rich galaxy

extractions.description: This paper presents JWST observations that detect the 3.3μm PAH feature in a galaxy observed less than 1.5 billion years after the Big Bang. The study analyzes the spatial variations in PAH equivalent width and the ratio of PAH to total infrared luminosity across the galaxy, suggesting physical offsets between PAHs and large dust grains or wide variations in the local ultraviolet radiation field.

type.justification: The paper involves observations and data analysis from JWST, which are typical characteristics of empirical research.
type.quote: Here we present JWST observations that detect the 3.3μm PAH feature in a galaxy observed less than 1.5 billion years after the Big Bang.

name.justification: The paper deals with the observation of a galaxy and the analysis of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, which falls under the field of astrophysics.
name.quote: Observations of PAH features in very distant galaxies have been difficult due to the limited sensitivity and wavelength coverage of previous infrared telescopes.

name.justification: The study focuses on a galaxy observed by JWST, thus it is strongly related to astronomy.
name.quote: We observed the galaxy SPT0418-47 (SPT-S J041839-4751.9) as part of the Targeting Extremely Magnified Panchromatic Lensed Arcs and Their Extended Star formation (TEMPLATES) Early Release Science program on JWST.

name.justification: The dataset refers to observations of the galaxy SPT0418-47.
name.quote: Subsequent observations with the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) confirmed SPT0418-47 as a z =4.2248 galaxy magnified by a factor of ~30-35 by strong gravitational lensing into a hallmark Einstein ring morphology by a foreground galaxy at z = 0.263.

referenced_paper_title.value: ALMA Redshifts of Millimeter-selected Galaxies from the SPT Survey: The Redshift Distribution of Dusty Star-forming Galaxies
referenced_paper_title.justification: This paper is referenced for the data on galaxy SPT0418-47 used in the current study.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Weiß, A. et al. ALMA Redshifts of Millimeter-selected Galaxies from the SPT Survey: The Redshift Distribution of Dusty Star-forming Galaxies. Astrophys. J. 767, 88 (2013).

name.justification: The dataset is part of the TEMPLATES Early Release Science program on JWST.
name.quote: We observed the galaxy SPT0418-47 (SPT-S J041839-4751.9) as part of the Targeting Extremely Magnified Panchromatic Lensed Arcs and Their Extended Star formation (TEMPLATES) Early Release Science program on JWST.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The TEMPLATES Program is a named dataset, thus does not necessarily have a specific referenced paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We observed the galaxy SPT0418-47 (SPT-S J041839-4751.9) as part of the Targeting Extremely Magnified Panchromatic Lensed Arcs and Their Extended Star formation (TEMPLATES) Early Release Science program on JWST.

name.justification: The paper mentions the usage of the JWST pipeline software for processing the JWST data.
name.quote: We processed the JWST data with the JWST pipeline software, including additional background subtraction and data artifact removal techniques (Methods).

referenced_paper_title.justification: The JWST Pipeline is a software tool rather than a study and thus does not have a reference paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We processed the JWST data with the JWST pipeline software, including additional background subtraction and data artifact removal techniques (Methods).

name.justification: The data were reduced using standard pipeline scripts, which refers to the CASA framework for radio astronomy data processing.
name.quote: The data were reduced using standard pipeline scripts, and we performed a single round of phase-only self-calibration for each execution of the observing blocks. We jointly imaged the data using natural weighting of the visibilities, accounting for the primary beam response differences due to the different phase centers between the two ALMA projects.

referenced_paper_title.justification: CASA is a standard tool for reducing radio astronomy data and does not have a specific referenced paper in the context of this use.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The data were reduced using standard pipeline scripts, and we performed a single round of phase-only self-calibration for each execution of the observing blocks.
